maml:description.maml:para: Disables the DNS64 configuration on a computer.
The Disable-NetDnsTransitionConfiguration makes the DNS64 configuration ineffective on a computer.
Specifies the network adapter on which to disable the DNS64.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the DNS64 configuration object to disable.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the network adapter on which to disable the DNS64.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example makes the DNS64 configuration ineffective.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables the DNS64 configuration on a computer.
The Enable-NetDnsTransitionConfiguration makes the DNS64 configuration effective on a computer.
Specifies the network adapter on which to enable the DNS64.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example makes the DNS64 configuration effective.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the DNS64 configuration of a computer.

The Get-NetDnsTransitionConfiguration cmdlet retrieves the DNS64 configuration of a computer. DNS64 is described in the RFC 6147. DNS64 is used with an IPv6/IPv4 translator to enable client-server communication between an IPv6-only client and an IPv4-only server, without requiring any changes to either the IPv6 or the IPv4 node.
Specifies the network adapter from which to retrieve the configuration information.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the network adapter from which to retrieve the configuration information.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.
The MSFT_NetDnsTransitionConfiguration object contains the DNS64 configuration.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example retrieves the DNS64 configuration of a computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Resets the DNS64 configuration on a computer.
The Reset-NetDnsTransitionConfiguration resets the settings for the DNS64 configuration with the default settings.
Resets the interface on which the DNS64 is listening to all interfaces classified in the Domain profile.
Specifies the network adapter on which to apply the reset.
Specifies that the DNS64 will always synthesize responses by sending both the AAAA response and well as the synthesized A response, when set to False.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Resets to the list of IPv6 address ranges to be excluded from synthesis by the DNS64 to ::ffff:0:0/96.
Resets to the default value of 300 ms for the delay between the AAAA and A query that the DNS64 sends.
Specifies that both A and AAAA queries will be sent, when set to False.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Resets to the list of IPv6 address ranges to be excluded from synthesis by the DNS64 to 64:FF9B::/96, 0.0.0.0/0.
Resets the interface on which the DNS64 sends DNS queries to all interface classified in the Domain profile.
Resets the state of the DNS64 configuration to disabled.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Resets the interface on which the DNS64 is listening to all interfaces classified in the Domain profile.
Specifies that the DNS64 will always synthesize responses by sending both the AAAA response and well as the synthesized A response, when set to False.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Resets to the list of IPv6 address ranges to be excluded from synthesis by the DNS64 to ::ffff:0:0/96.
Resets to the default value of 300 ms for the delay between the AAAA and A query that the DNS64 sends.
Specifies that both A and AAAA queries will be sent, when set to False.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Resets to the list of IPv6 address ranges to be excluded from synthesis by the DNS64 to 64:FF9B::/96, 0.0.0.0/0.
Resets the interface on which the DNS64 sends DNS queries to all interface classified in the Domain profile.
Resets the state of the DNS64 configuration to disabled.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the DNS64 configuration object to reset.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Resets the interface on which the DNS64 is listening to all interfaces classified in the Domain profile.
Specifies the network adapter on which to apply the reset.
Specifies that the DNS64 will always synthesize responses by sending both the AAAA response and well as the synthesized A response, when set to False.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Specifies that both A and AAAA queries will be sent, when set to False.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example resets the state and latency of the DNS64 configuration.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the DNS64 configuration on a computer.
The Set-NetDnsTransitionConfiguration sets the DNS64 configuration on a computer.
Specifies the interface on which the DNS64 is listening to all of the interfaces classified in the domain profile.
Specifies the network adapter on which to set.

Specifies that the DNS64 will always send both the response to the AAAA query as well as the synthesized A query response. If this parameter is set to False, then the DNS64 will send neither the response to the AAAA query nor the synthesized A query response.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Sets the list of IPv6 address ranges to be excluded from synthesis by the DNS64. The format is a comma-separated list of IPv6 addresses ranges.
Sets the delay in milliseconds between the AAAA and A query that the DNS64 sends.

Specifies that only A queries should be sent or both A and AAAA queries should be sent. If this parameter is set to True, then only A queries should be sent. If this parameter is set to False, then both A and AAAA queries should be sent.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Sets to the list of IPv6 address ranges to be used for synthesis by the DNS64. The format is a comma-separated list of <IPv6 prefix,IPv4 subnet>. Such as "69:FF9B::/96,0.0.0.0/0","66:FF9B::/96,192.2.0.0/8".
Sets the interface on which the DNS64 sends DNS queries.
Sets the enabled state of the DNS64 configuration.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the interface on which the DNS64 is listening to all of the interfaces classified in the domain profile.

Specifies that the DNS64 will always send both the response to the AAAA query as well as the synthesized A query response. If this parameter is set to False, then the DNS64 will send neither the response to the AAAA query nor the synthesized A query response.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Sets the list of IPv6 address ranges to be excluded from synthesis by the DNS64. The format is a comma-separated list of IPv6 addresses ranges.
Sets the delay in milliseconds between the AAAA and A query that the DNS64 sends.

Specifies that only A queries should be sent or both A and AAAA queries should be sent. If this parameter is set to True, then only A queries should be sent. If this parameter is set to False, then both A and AAAA queries should be sent.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Sets to the list of IPv6 address ranges to be used for synthesis by the DNS64. The format is a comma-separated list of <IPv6 prefix,IPv4 subnet>. Such as "69:FF9B::/96,0.0.0.0/0","66:FF9B::/96,192.2.0.0/8".
Sets the interface on which the DNS64 sends DNS queries.
Sets the enabled state of the DNS64 configuration.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the DNS64 configuration object on which to set.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the interface on which the DNS64 is listening to all of the interfaces classified in the domain profile.
Specifies the network adapter on which to set.

Specifies that the DNS64 will always send both the response to the AAAA query as well as the synthesized A query response. If this parameter is set to False, then the DNS64 will send neither the response to the AAAA query nor the synthesized A query response.

To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the state to enabled and latency to 400 ms for the DNS64 configuration.
